ሰላም፡ ለከ፡ ኢያቄም፡ አረጋዊ። ወላዴ፡ ማርያም፡ ወለተ፡ ዳዊት፡ ዕንቃዊ። ሰላ፡ ም፡ ሳይሆን፡ እግዚአብሔር፡ ይፍታችሁ፡ ከመ፡ ትርከቡ፡ እሤተ፡ በወለታ፡ ፍቃዳችሁ፡
ዝምጽሐፍ፡ ዘኢያቄም፡ ወሐና፡ ትብጻሕ፡ ኀበ፡ ገበዘ፡ አኩስም፡ ርእሰ፡ ኵሉ፡ ታቦታት። ኵሉ፡ የሐልፍ፡ ዘኢተሐልፍ። ዘአጽሐፋ፡ አባ፡ ገብረ፡ ማርያም፡ ዘወለድዎ፡ ዲያቆን፡ አምደ፡ ጽዮን። የመምሕር፡ ተጠምቀ፡ መድኅን፡ ልጅ። ዘጸሐፋ፡ ገብረ፡ ክርስቶስ፡ ዘሰአላ፡ ሐብተ፡ ገብርኤል፡ ዘአስላ፡ ወዘአጽሐፈ፡ አባ፡ ገብረ፡ ማርያም፡ ወዘፃራ፡ አባ፡ ወልደ፡ ሥላሴ፡ ጥቡዕ፡ መናኒ። ወዘምራን፡ አኩስም፡ ማኅሌተ፡ ኢታኅጕሉ፡ በዓመታ፡ The colophon is written in Gǝʿǝz and Amharic. It states that the manuscript was commissioned by ʾAbbā Gabra Māryām, son of the deacon , at the time of rās Walda Śǝllāse. The colophon also states that the manuscript was copied by and illustrated by . Other individuals are mentioned: ʾAbbā Walda Garimā, ʾAbbā ʾAnāniqos, , and ʾAbbā Walda Śǝllāse. According to the colophon, the book was written in the monastery of , in . Two short salām-hymns in honour of Anne and Joachim are embedded in the colophon. They are separated with chains of red and black dots or with black and red lines.

supportDesc.foliation: Pencil foliation in the upper right corner (10–79). The first nine and last two folios are not foliated; the foliation begins with the number 10 on . The unfoliated folios are referred to as and in this description. A protective bifolio has been glued to the front and back cover and has not been considered in the foliation.

signatures.note: Quire marks are written in the upper inner margin of the first folio of quires 4–8, respectively marked with Ethiopic numerals as 2–6. All quire marks are written in black and red ink and are surrounded by four nine-dot signs, also executed in red and black ink.

decoDesc.summary:
The manuscript contains a prefatory cycle of full-page miniatures (), which include two uncommon representations of Joachim and Anna. The images in this volume were first described by Budge, who described them as "archaic" and mistakenly attributed them to the 15th century (vii). In fact, the miniatures actually belong to the turn of the 19th century and are painted in the Šawān style ( 469–524). These images must be more or less contemporary with the production of the manuscript since one of them features its patron, . The style and poses of the figures in the miniatures, as well as the palaeography of their captions, are almost identical to those seen in a set of miniatures found at the end of EMML 2349. The name of the scribe who worked on the EMML manuscript (414) is different from that who authored this example. This suggests that in at least one, if not both examples, the scribe and illuminator were different individuals, thus confirming the information provided in the colophon on fol. 10v that identifies the artist as .
The manuscript also contains several headpieces. They are inserted in empty lines, which suggests they were planned as additions, during the writing, but they are slightly different from the decorations that appear in EMML 2349, which leads to the question about whether or not they were painted by the artist responsible for the figurative cycle of illuminations.

binding.decoNote: The book is bound in wooden boards. An older blind-tooled leather, perhaps contemporary with the majority of the manuscript's content, covers them entirely and a new leather quarter cover has been added on top.
The boards are flush with the bookblock and have internal shallow bevels.

The earlier blind-tooled cover is preserved, despite deteriorated, under the present one. The decoration is partially legible on the edges, where it shows a pattern of double circles. The present leather is blind-tooled as well but covers only the spine and partially the boards. On its surface bands of two single straight lines intersect forming a column of juxtaposed panels. Within each panel, the lines cross each other forming a crux decussata and at the intersections of the lines, double circles are stamped. The back features only straight single lines outlining its perimeter. The edges of the thick leather cover are nailed to the boards and decorated with double circles.

Chainstitch sewing on four sewing stations (two pairs); periodic fold pattern. Two S-plied threads are used. The sewing starts from the first quire where, for each pair of sewing stations, there is one length of thread. In the rest of the quires the lenghts are two. The ends of the thread are knotted in the last quire.
The stitches of four endband chains are sewn into the leather of the spine, two being close to the head and two to the tail.

A blue leaf tab marker for navigating the text is inserted in the upper corner of (incipit page of the reading for Friday), (incipit page of the reading for Saturday), and (incipit page of the reading for Sunday).

history.origin: According to , the manuscript was written by in the monastery of , in , under the patronage of ʾAbbā Gabra Māryām. It was written at the time of Rās Walda Śǝllāse.
history.provenance:
The manuscript was brought to England by a British officer after the 1868 expedition by , in all likelihood coming from the collection. It was then sold to the and in 1897, after failed negotiations with the , it entered the private collection of as ms. Lady Meux 4. The manuscript was inspected and its textual contents edited and translated by , who had been asked to examine it by . After Lady Meux's death, in 1911, the manuscript was probably sold. The subsequent owners are unknown, but the manuscript was eventually purchased at a Fine Oriental Manuscripts and Miniatures auction at Sotheby's on 16 April 1985 (lot 392), according to the auction catalogue. The circumstances of the last acquisition are also described in
